title-group.article-title: Multi-resonance capturing in a two-degree-of-freedom system under two different harmonic excitations

article-meta.aff: Université de Lyon, ENTPE, DGCB, FRE CNRS 3237, Vaulx-en-Velin Cedex, France

author-notes.corresp: Alireza Ture Savadkoohi, Université de Lyon, ENTPE, DGCB, FRE CNRS 3237, 3 rue Maurice Audin, 69518 Vaulx-en-Velin Cedex, France Email: alireza.turesavadkoohi@entpe.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper we consider two coupled oscillators which exhibit energy transfer from master ‘linear’ degrees of freedom submitted to resonant external excitation with two different harmonics to a slave ‘nonlinear’ energy sink (NES). By endowing the idea of the relative mode, splitting harmonics and iterative techniques, we prove that control of the two one-to-one resonances of the system is possible simultaneously; moreover, the iterative technique gives us a better outlook over effects of the NES parameters on the overall behavior of the system. Then, analytical procedure for multi-resonance capture are explained and commented on. Finally, the obtained analytical results are compared with numerical evidence.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Numerous mitigation devices have been developed during the last few decades (De Silva, 2005). Novel designs of structures commonly seek to reduce the total structural mass. Thus, it is important to develop new absorption devices that reduce both stationary and transient responses as much as possible while adding as little extra mass to the structure as possible; moreover, these devices should be able to absorb the effects of external solicitations for a broad band of frequencies. To this end, the nonlinear energy sink (NES) system has been developed so that the imposed energy to a linear degree of freedom (DoF) system is transferred to one or some of strongly nonlinear light attachments in an almost irreversible manner; the mechanism is based on resonance(s) captures. Theoretical background of these systems is quite well developed (Gendelman et al., 2001; Vakakis, 2001; Vakakis and Gendelman, 2001; Vakakis, 2003; Gendelman, 2004; Gendelman and Lamarque, 2005; Gendelman et al., 2006; Musienko et al., 2006; Manevitch et al., 2007a; Vakakis et al., 2009a,2009b). Manevitch et al. (2007b,2007c) presented a new analytical approach to the problem of energy pumping in strongly nonhomogeneous nonlinear 2-DoF systems with a single anchor spring under condition of an initial impact. Their approach was based on the application of the equations of motion in a complex form and using the power expansion of the solution in terms of time. Manevitch and Manevitch (2009) presented an analytical and numerical study of the energy exchange and transfer in a strongly nonlinear 2-DoF system subject to resonance one-to-one based on the concept of the limiting phase trajectories. Their approach allowed the construction of an approximate analytic solution describing the energy exchange and beating with complete energy transfer in the system. The effect of the NES on the steady-state dynamics of a coupled system was studied experimentally and theoretically by Jiang et al. (2003), while more mature studies of these systems under harmonic forcing by considering the bifurcation and stability of fixed points are pointed out by Starosvetsky and Gendelman (2008a). The same authors studied quasi-periodic response of this system under external sinusoidal forcing in the vicinity of one-to-one resonance (Gendelman and Starosvetsky, 2007); they revealed two qualitatively different regimes of the quasi-periodic response. The first appears as a result of linear instability of the steady-state regime of the oscillations. The second occurs due to interaction of the dynamical flow with invariant manifold of the damped–forced nonlinear normal mode of the system, resulting in hysteretic motion of the flow in the vicinity of this mode. The dynamic responses of this compound system under harmonic forcing in the regime of one-to-one-to-one resonance was the subject of a detailed investigation of the strongly modulated response which is not related to the fixed points of average modulation equations of the system by Starosvetsky and Gendelman (2008b). The importance of higher frequencies of the NES which is attached to a linear single DoF system based on the definition of relative modes is pinpointed by Pham et al. (2010b) In the practical field, McFarland et al. (2005), Gourdon et al. (2007a, 2007b) and Ture Savadkoohi et al. (2009) experimentally showed the efficiency of NES devices on the absorption of the main part of the externally induced forces to structures.

In this paper, a compound 2-DoF system with the attached NES is investigated. The paper is organized as follows. Different mathematical illustrations of the system and splitting harmonics method are explained in Section 2. Simple and complex localizations of relative modes by distinguishing the distance between center frequencies of the master substructure are addressed in Sections 3 and 4, respectively. Some numerical examples are given and discussed. Finally, the paper is concluded in Section 5.

sec.title: 2. The mathematical models of the system under consideration
sec.p:
The academic model of the depicted dynamical system in Figure 1 is as follows: (1) where M1, M2, k1, k2, c1 and c2 are masses, stiffnesses and damping ratios of components of the linear master system, while m, k3 and c3 are the mass, cubic stiffness and damping ratio of the NES, respectively; x, y and z are displacements of masses M1, M2 and m, respectively; f1(t) and f2(t) are external solicitations of the system. In this study we suppose that these forces are composed of both resonance frequencies of the linear master system and we do not consider other kinds of solicitations. Mass, damping and stiffness matrices of the linear master system, i.e. M, C and K, respectively, are defined as follows: (2) (3) (4) and if we assume that and F is the following external forcing vector: (5) Then the system (1) can be rewritten as (6) Figure 1.
The compound dynamical system.

Let us shift the model from the physical domain to the modal domain by changing variables with the X = ϕq system. X, ϕ and q are displacements of linear DoFs, the mode shape matrix and the modal coordinate vector, respectively: (7) (8) (9)

Modal mass and modal stiffness matrices, i.e. Mmodal and Kmodal, respectively have the form (10) (11) By endowing the Basile's hypothesis, the damping matrix in the modal domain Cmodal will be diagonal: (12) where t denotes the transpose operation on a matrix. With the above-mentioned definitions, the system (6) can be re-scaled in the modal domain as follows: (13) Let us define y1 = ϕ12q1, y2 = ϕ22q2, y = y1 + y2,
then the system (1) takes following form: (14) where f˜1(t) and f˜2(t) are evaluated as (15) A new variable w is introduced in the following form which is in fact the relative displacement between yandz: (16) then, Equation (14) will read as (17) Let us consider a special case where (18) This means that the forcing term on mode 1 is zero while the forcing term on mode 2 is associated with the frequency of mode 1, i.e. ω1; then the NES transmits the excitation with the frequency ω1 to the mode 1 and this will create a one-to-one resonance. A similar behavior can be foreseen about the mode 2 if the following excitation condition is available (19) Since governing equations of the systems with tuned mass dampers (TMDs) are quite similar to (17), butlinear in terms of w, they will present the above-mentioned drawback as well. This reverse vibrating pumping to the master system is a typical drawback of attached linear and nonlinear absorbers in multi-DoF master systems under the mentioned forcing conditions.

For the current study we consider following forcingprotocol as the external solicitations of the system: (20) where ω1f ≈ ω1 and ω2f ≈ ω2; so, these forces are composed of both resonance frequencies of the linear master system. If we assume that Ajk, j = 1, 2; k = 1, 2; are at thesame order of magnitudes, then each mode will be excited mainly by the forcing term which contains the frequency of the same mode.

sec.title: 2.1. Splitting harmonics and iterative techniques
sec.p: We can split modes y1 and y2 into harmonics as follows: (21) where y11 and y21 are those harmonics which are associated with the ω1f and y12 and y22 are related to the ω2f. Moreover, the relative mode can be defined as sum of harmonics as follows: (22) where n counts considered harmonics, n ≥ 2; w1 and w2 are harmonics associated with the frequencies ω1f and ω2f, respectively; wl, l = 3,…, n are the harmonics associated with frequencies ωwl which are different from ω1f and ω2f. The wl, l = 3,…, n will be considered in the case of complex resonance.

Substituting the formal separation (21) and (22) into the system of Equations (17), one obtains (23) Now, the Manevitch's complex variables (Manevitch, 1999) are introduced as (24) so that (25) where c.c. denotes the complex conjugate term and i=−1.

By applying change of variables which are introduced in (25) into the three equations of the system (23), we obtain a system of three equations: (26) where (27) where Ajk = Ajk eiθjk, j = 1, 2 and k = 1, 2.
Steady-state solutions of the system can be clarified by imposing following criteria to the system: (28) The system (26) will read as (29) (30)

We can rewrite the Ψ˜ m0, m = 1,…, 3 in the form: (31) where Fjk, Hl, Fk, Fl; j, k = 1,…, 2, l = 3,…, n depend onφjk, φk and φl. We can neglect the term ∑l=3n(Hleiωwlt+c.c.) by assuming that it is small compared to the rest which includes the resonant terms in the first two equations with solicitation. This assumption point has to be verified in the application of the method except if n = 2. From Equations (31) and since eiωkft, k = 1,…, 2 and eiωwlt, l = 3,…, n are independent vectors in ℂ–vector space of function from ℝ to ℂ; one obtains (32) So, we obtain n + 4 equations of n + 4 unknown φ and this system can be solved.

sec.title: 3. A case study: simple localization of relative mode
sec.p: Let us consider the simplest case when the relative mode is localized by only two excitation frequencies, namely ω1f and ω2f (localization type is determined by all NES parameters). We are seeking for the resonance between the nonlinear mode and linear eigenmodes of the master system; there are two one-to-one resonances. According to Equation (22) we have (33) where w1 and w2 are parts of vibration that are associated with the frequencies ω1f and ω2f, respectively. With the procedure which is explained in the previous section, the system of (32) will read as (34) (35) The two systems of equations are valid in the general case except for the case where ω2f = 3ω1f; here, more resonant terms have to be considered: φ13 is in resonance with φ2 and φ2φ¯ 12 is in resonance with φ1. Two different cases which are depending on the distance between ω1 and ω2 are described and analyzed in the following sections.

sec.title: 3.1. Well-separated two center frequencies
sec.p: Let us assume that two center frequencies of the mechanical system under consideration are well separated, i.e. (36) Considering that ω1f and ω2f are close enough to ω1 and ω2, respectively, and Ajk, j = 1, 2 and k = 1,2 are at the same order of magnitude, then that part of y1 associated with the frequency ω2f, i.e. φ12 and that part of y2 associated with the frequency ω1f, i.e. φ21, are small compared with φ11 and φ22, respectively. By removing the two small quantities (φ12 and φ21) in the systems (34) and (35) we obtain (37) (38)This simplification creates two sets of equations which are almost identical to the control of a single-DoF dynamical system by a NES (Starosvetsky and Gendelman, 2008a). This simplification makes the twomodes, namely mode 1 (i.e. φ11) and mode 2 (i.e. φ22), well separated. In the absence of the term 32iKφ1|φ2|2 which is linear with the φ1 in (37), the system will describe the control of the mode 1 in a one-to-one resonance. In a general case and if we consider that |φ2|2 is a constant, then solving (37) is similar to solving a classical transfer equation; it means that an equivalent model with a linear spring will beadded to the system whose stiffness is proportionalto|φ2|2 with non-linear absorber (Pham et al. 2010a). The Same procedure can be repeated for the mode ϕ2.

The following equalities can be defined from two first equations of systems (37) and (38) between different modes of the system: (39) where (40) By substituting these variables to the second equations of systems (37) and (38), following compact forms of equations can be defined: (41) where (42) The system (41) can be re-written in the following form: (43) Gk, k = 1, 2 are polynomials of degree three with respect to Zk whose parameters depend on Zl, l ∈ {1, 2} and l ≠ k, Zj = |φj|2, j = 1, 2: (44) where η11r = ℜ(η11), η11i = ℑ(η11), η21r = ℜ(η21), η21i = ℑ(η21). Symbols ℜ(·) and ℑ(·) represent real and imaginary parts of a complex number, respectively.
A novel iterative technique for solving the system of (43) has been developed by Pham et al. (2010b); a general view of this technique is summarized in the Appendix A.

sec.title: 3.1.1. Numerical example
sec.p:
In the academic model of the dynamical system which is depicted in Figure 1, we assume that f1 = 1.73 (Hz), ζ1 = 0.1% × 2ω1, f2 = 4.53 (Hz), ζ2 = 0.1% × 2ω2, which are in fact parameters of a two-storey structure (Gourdon, 2006); moreover, the following excitation parameters are assumed: A11 = 0.5, A12 = 0.0, A21 = 0.0, A22 = 0.7, ω1f = ω1 + σ1ε1 and ω2f = ω2 + σ2ε2 where σ1 and σ2 are detuning parameters. By implementing the iterative method and checking the responses of the system with different NES parameters, we were able to trace appropriate NES parameters for the periodic regime of the system; the parameters of the NES are: ϵ1=180, ϵ2=131, K = 54 and λ = 2ω1. The assumed initial conditions for all examples of this article are as follows: (45)
Example 1
Let us suppose that σ2 = 0, so ω2f = ω2 and the parameter σ1 = σ sweeps the interval [−80, 80], i.e. ω1f ∈ [ω1 − 1, ω1 + 1]. The variation of displacements of mode 1 (y1) and of mode 2 (y2) with respect to the detuning parameter σ for the system with and without absorber are presented in Figures 2 and 4, while change of amplitudes of w1 and w2 with respect to the same parameter are illustrated in Figures 3 and 5. Figure 2.
Modal displacement |y1| vs. σ. Figure 3.
Modal displacement |w1| vs. σ. Figure 4.
Modal displacement |y2| vs. σ. Figure 5.
Modal displacement |w2| vs. σ.
Example 2
Now we suppose that σ1 = 0, so ω1f = ω1 and the parameter σ2 = σ sweeps the interval [−30, 30], i.e. ω2f ∈ [ω2 − 1, ω2 + 1]. The variation of displacements of mode 1 (y1) and of mode 2 (y2) with respect to the detuning parameter σ for the system with and without absorber are presented in Figures 6 and 8, while change of amplitudes of w1 and w2 with respect to the same parameter are illustrated in Figures 7 and 9. Figure 6.
Modal displacement |y1| vs. σ. Figure 7.
Modal displacement |w1| vs. σ. Figure 8.
Modal displacement |y2| vs. σ. Figure 9.
Modal displacement |w2| vs. σ. The presented results in both examples show the effectiveness of the iterative technique in detecting the actual behavior of the system which is affected by the NES parameters.
These results reveal that simultaneous control of two one-to-one and one-to-one resonances by a single NES is possible and efficient (see Figures 2, 4, 6 and 8).

Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5 show that when the pulsation ω2f is constant and ω1f varies, the amplitude of the localized vibration mode 1 (|φ1|) varies greatly but theamplitude of the localized mode 2 (|φ2|) is not sensitive to ω1f. A similar effect can be explored from Figures 6, 7, 8 and 9 when ω1f is constant and ω2f is varying.

statement.title: Example 3
statement.p: Let us take the same parameters as in Example 1, but with a randomly smaller value for λ: we suppose that λ = 0.09ω1.

sec.p:
The simulation is carried out during 2,048 periods of frequency ω1, then the maximum values of |y1| and |y2| are taken from the last 512 periods as the responses in these periods can be considered as in a steady state. Variation of the maximum values of |y1| and |y2| with respect to the detuning parameter σ for the system with and without an absorber are presented in Figures 10 and 11. One can see that the steady-state response traps into another regime when σ ∈ [−11.67, 23.07] which belongs to the quasi-periodic response (Gendelman et al., 2006; Starosvetsky and Gendelman, 2008a). Although in the given example the NES can control the structure against externally induced oscillations and the transfer of energy is observed, but the response regime during this phenomenon is different from previous examples which were in the periodic regime that is the fundamental assumption of this article. Moreover, the given example shows the complicated influences of the NES parameters which can change the behavior of the whole system and lead theresponse of the system to other regimes. As a summary, in the given example the choice of resonance andthe dynamical regime do not correspond to the main assumption of analytical iterative procedure. Nevertheless, one can see via this example that energy transfer is still efficient but analysis of the transfer will need other types of investigations. Figure 10.
Modal displacement |y1| vs. σ. Figure 11.
Modal displacement |y2| vs. σ.

sec.title: 3.2. Two center frequencies are not well separated
sec.p: If frequencies of the master substructure are close to each other, we can suppose that (46) Since ω1f is close to ω1, then it will be close to ω2 as well; so the excitation terms will excite both modes of the system simultaneously. Let us consider the case where the relative mode is located only according to two frequencies of the excitation (harmonics are weak). In the system of Equation (34), a subsystem of linear equations in terms of φ11 and φ21 which are functions of the φ1 can be obtained as follows: (47) A similar system can be derived from system of Equations (35) for φ12 and φ22 which are functions of the φ2: (48) Let us assume the following relationships between φ11, φ21, φ1, φ12, φ22 and φ2: (49) (50) Coefficients αjkl, j = 1, 2, k = 1, 2, l = 0, 1, are determined by the system parameters. By substituting (49) and (50) into the third equations of systems (34) and (35), a set of equations with unknown φ1 and φ2 are obtained. These equations have the same general form as the system (41) and their solutions can be traced by implementing the iterative technique (Pham et al., 2010b).

sec.title: 4. The concept of the complex localization
sec.p: One of the outstanding characteristics of NES devices is the possibility of multiple localization. We present some kinds of resonances and the application of the iterative technique for managing governing equations of the system. Different resonances are separated according to different harmonics. The NES is activated by two frequencies of solicitations and the nonlinear innate of the NES combines these frequencies to create harmonics. Depending on the distance between two center frequencies of the master system the combination of generated harmonics changes.

sec.title: 4.1. Well-separated two center frequencies
sec.p:
The given criterion in (36) is used to check the validity of the well separation of two center frequencies. We can choose as many as auxiliary frequencies for a relative mode and the area of localization can present the resonance frequencies exactly. As an example we focus on a relative mode that has two excitation frequencies ω1f, ω2f and a combined frequency ω2f − 2ω1f. The separation of harmonics which are given in (21) and (22) can be endowed for further investigations: (51) where wr21 is the part of the relative mode which is connected to the frequency ω2f − 2ω1f, whose complex amplitude is (52) Based on the above-mentioned definitions, the following systems of algebraic equations can be obtained:
The system of equations which are connected to the frequency ω1f: (53)
The system of equations which are connected to the frequency ω2f: (54)
The system of equations which are connected to the frequency ω2f − 2ω1f: (55)
The iterative technique can be applied for solving these systems of equations; but by implementing some simplifying assumptions we can solve the system faster without any need for evaluating phases. This task can be carried out by eliminations y12 in y1 and y21 in y2; this will yield following system equations:
The system of equations which are connected to the frequency ω1f: (56)
The system of equations which are connected to the frequency ω2f: (57)
The equation which is connected to the frequency ω2f − 2ω1f: (58)
The relations of (39) are always deducted from the firstequations of (56) and (57) and by substituting it into the second equations of the same systems, we obtain: (59) where coefficients ηjk, j = 1, 2, k = 0,…, 3 are identical to those of (41) and the ηj4, j = 1, 2 are determined by the parameters of the system. Equation (58) can be rewritten as (60) so (61) By substituting evaluated φr21 only in terms 32iKφ¯ 1φ2φ¯ r21 and 34iKφ12φr21 of the system (59), one can reach the following system of equations: (62) By applying the iterative technique to the algebraic system of Equations (62), the system will be solved faster without any need to evaluate phases of the system and we will be able to observe the effect of the NES parameters on the behavior of the system.

sec.title: 4.1.1. Numerical example
sec.p:
Let us assume following parameters for the main system and excitation: f1 = 1.73 (Hz), ζ1 = 0.1% × 2ω1, f2 = 4.53 (Hz), ζ2 = 0.1% × 2ω2, A11 = 0.5, A12 = 0.0, A21 = 0.0, A22 = 1.7, ω1f = ω1 + ε1 σ1, σ1 = 0 and ω2f = ω2 + ε2 σ2, σ2 = 0. With the study presented by Pham et al. (2010b), one can choose the following NES parameters: ϵ1=180, ϵ2=160, K = 1,000, λ = 0.5 × 2ω1. Analytical and numerical results are gathered in Table 1. Table 1.
Analytical and numerical results
Absolute value of mode |φ1| |φ2| |φr21|
Analytical results 0.1548256500 0.1410751762 0.01717957566
Numerical results 0.1548 0.1332 0.01668

Table 1 and the response spectrum which is obtained by the numerical method and is depicted in Figure 12 illustrate good agreements between numerical and analytical results. Figure 12.
Frequency spectrum of the relative displacement w in a case of multiple resonance.

Now, let us define the two following functions: (63) which are energy signatures of two modes of the master system. Evolutions of these signatures with time for the system with NES (E1NES, E2NES) and without NES (E1free, E2free) are illustrated in Figures 13 and 14. These figures show the efficiency of the compound nonlinear system in transferring the energy of modes to the NES and reducing the energy level of each modes to considerable levels. Figure 13.
Energy signature of mode 1, y1. Figure 14.
Energy signature of mode 2, y2.

sec.title: 4.2. Two center frequencies are not well separated
sec.p: Prediction of harmonics in the case of two well-separated frequencies of the master system is not as straightforward as in the case when they are close to each other (condition (46)). In the latter case, we can analyze multiple resonances of a ‘single’ DoF master system with the frequencies close to center frequencies of the main system. Let us suppose that ω2f − ω1f is small, that ω1f − (ω2f − ω1f) and ω2f + (ω2f − ω1f) are very close to ω1f and ω2f, respectively. Therefore, we can consider relevant harmonics of these frequencies in the relative mode for the purpose of separation: (64) where w012 and w021 are parts of vibrations at the frequency 2ω1f − ω2f and 2ω2f − ω1f, respectively. Complex variables are introduced as follows: (65)

Different systems of equations can be re-written according to the following categories:
System of equations which are connected to the frequency ω1f: (66)
System of equations which are connected to the frequency ω2f: (67)
The equation which is connected to the frequency 2ω1f − ω2f: (68)
The equation which is connected to the frequency 2ω2f − ω1f: (69)
According to the expression of the modal displacement, φjj, j ∈ {1, 2}, and the relative mode, φk, k ∈ T, T = {1, 2, 012, 021}, and by considering Equations (49) and (50), the following system of equations can be obtained: (70) with the parameters η0k′ corresponding to (71)

sec.title: 4.2.1. Numerical example
sec.p:
Let us consider following system, absorber and excitation parameters: f1 = 1.73 (Hz), ζ1 = 0.1% × 2ω1, f2 = 1.78 (Hz), ζ2 = 0.1% × 2ω2, ϵ1=180, ϵ2=160, K = 1,000, λ = 2ω1, A11 = 0.5, A12 = 0.5, A21 = 0.7, A22 = 0.7, ω1f = ω1 + ε1 σ1, σ1 = 0, ω2f = ω2 + ε2 σ2 and σ2 = 0. Analytical and numerical results of the response of the system are gathered in Table 2. Table 2.
Analytical and numerical results
Absolute value of mode |φ1| |φ2| |φ012| |φ021|
Analytical results 0.1517707539 0.1572205421 0.01243450558 0.01157861013
Numerical results 0.1517 0.1472 0.01047 0.01115

Moreover, numerical results for the frequency spectrum are presented in Figure 15; this figure and Table 2 indicate a good agreement between analytical and numerical results. Figure 15.
The frequency spectrum of relative displacement w in a case of multiple resonance.

Variation of the energy signatures for modes of the master substructure which are introduced in Equation (63) are illustrated in Figures 16 and 17 for the system with and without a NES. Figure 16.
Energy signature of mode 1, y1. Figure 17.
Energy signature of mode 2, y2.

Although there are some influences of the solicitation by the frequency of the mode 2 (ω2f) on the mode 1 (y1) (see curve E1free in Figure 16) and influence of the solicitation by the frequency of the mode 1 (ω1f) on the mode 2 (y2) (see curve E2free in Figure 17) in the system without NES, but by coupling the NES to the linear system, these influences are also reduced, i.e. the NES can control both sides of vibration in both coordinates simultaneously.

Tracing the boundary between different localization zones is pinpointed by Pham et al. (2010b). The localization depends mainly on the distance of center frequencies of the master system and optimal boundaries of the different localization zones can be evaluated by knowing all interfering system parameters.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: Control of a compound nonlinear forced system based on the definition of a relative mode and splitting harmonics was studied and pinpointed. Simple and complex localizations of the relative mode of the system were demonstrated by distinguishing the distance between frequencies of the master substructure. An iterative technique was implemented to reveal the actual behavior of the compound system which led us to understand the effects of the design parameters on the overall behavior of the system; the NES was able to take most of the energy of the master substructure and made it behave in a stable and a controlled manner.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work has been supported by Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR) in the frame of the project ADYNO ANR-07-BLAN-0193.

app.title: Appendix A: The iterative technique
app.p:
The objective of the iterative technique is to solve Equation (32) which is a complex system of algebraic equations for the amplitudes, i.e. φjk, φj. We always suppose that φ1 and φ2 are the complex amplitudes of the harmonics associated to the frequencies ω1 and ω2, respectively. In a general case, four equations of systems (47) and (48) are contained in the system (32) and they give relationships between harmonics of the main modes and harmonics of the relative mode in Equations (49) and (50). By applying systems of (49) and (50) on the original system of (32), following compact form of system of equations can be derived: (72) where φl, l = 1,…, n (n counts considered harmonics) are the amplitudes of harmonics of the relative mode, ρl0 = ρl0(φk), l = 1,…, n, k ∈ {1,…, n}, k ≠ l, are the remaining parts of the equations; for instance, in the considered case in Section 4.2 these remaining parts read as Equation (71), and ρlj, j = 1,…, 3, l = 1,…, n are determined by the system parameters. In the simplest case, Hl becomes Equation (41) where the notation ρ is replaced by η. The system (72) can be re-written in the form of equations for real amplitudes and phases, as follows: (73) (74) where φl=Nleiδl,{Nl,δj}⊂ℝ2 and Zl=Nl2, l=1,…,n. The real equation Kl(|Zl|)=|ρl0| in its simplest case hasthe same form with Equation (43). For evaluating |Zl| and δl, suggested procedure which is depicted in Figure 18 should be followed. Figure 18.
The algorithm of the iterative technique, where Zl,j is the value of Zl in the jth step, δl,j is the value of δl in the jth step, and r is a very small positive number standing for the accepted error.
